Expectation1: Communicate politely and professionally with customers
Situation1: The customer asks about the delivery status
Expectation2: Educate the public and the community about their cause.
Situation2: A social media post about your cause is currently going viral, and now is the perfect moment to add a comment with more information.
Story: My phone buzzes in my pocket as I ring the doorbell, the insulated bag heavy on my arm. The customer opens the door, frowning. “Where’s my order? It’s late,” she snaps. I force a polite smile, remembering the company’s training: always be courteous, always apologize. As I start to explain, my phone vibrates again—this time, a notification from the activist group I help run. Our latest post about environmental justice is going viral, and my friends are urging me to jump into the comments now, when people are paying attention. I know this is the moment to educate, to answer questions, to make a difference. But the customer is waiting, tapping her foot, expecting my full attention and professionalism. My mind races, torn between the immediate demand to be the perfect delivery person and the urgent call to be the voice my cause needs right now. I feel the pressure mounting, my words catching in my throat as I try to balance both worlds, knowing I can’t give either the attention they deserve.
